docs.lead_paragraph: Inmates are particularly prone to hepatitis C, a disease that can lead to fatal liver problems, posing practical and financial challenges for prison administrators.

headline.seo: Better Hepatitis C Treatment Is Costly for Texas Prisons
headline.main: Better Hepatitis C Treatment Is Costly for Prisons
headline.print_headline: Better Hepatitis C Treatment Is Costly for Prisons

docs.snippet: Inmates are particularly prone to hepatitis C, a disease that can lead to fatal liver problems, posing practical and financial challenges for prison administrators.

docs.lead_paragraph: The share of kindergartners whose parents have opted out of state immunization requirements more than doubled in the decade that ended in 2008, raising alarm among public health experts.

headline.seo: Washington State Makes It Harder to Forgo Immunizations
headline.main: Washington State Makes It Harder to Opt Out of Immunizations
headline.print_headline: Washington State Makes It Harder to Opt Out of Immunizations

docs.abstract: Share of Washington State kindergartners whose parents have opted out of immunization requirements has more than doubled in the decade that ended in 2008, raising alarm among public health experts; study published in The New England Journal of Medicine shows that more parents are choosing not to have their children vaccinated, especially in states that make it easy to opt out.
docs.snippet: The share of kindergartners whose parents have opted out of state immunization requirements more than doubled in the decade that ended in 2008, raising alarm among public health experts.

docs.lead_paragraph: A slow but steady accumulation of evidence is inspiring some experts to re-examine assumptions about the role of body fat in certain chronic diseases.

headline.seo: More Data Suggests Fitness Matters More Than Weight
headline.main: In ‘Obesity Paradox,’ Thinner May Mean Sicker
headline.print_headline: In ‘Obesity Paradox,’ Thinner May Mean Sicker

docs.abstract: Researchers have been puzzled by phenomenon known as the obesity paradox, in which overweight or obese patients with certain chronic diseases live longer and fare better than normal-weight patients with the same ailments; evidence is inspiring some experts to re-examine assumptions about the role of body fat in relation to these diseases.
docs.snippet: A slow but steady accumulation of evidence is inspiring some experts to re-examine assumptions about the role of body fat in certain chronic diseases.
